content.description: Taco Cat is a nice step up from 'Flow Wolf' next door, and very different in style. Sit down start, right hand on a slopey jug and left on a crimp. Work out the compression moves and a hard transition over the bulge to gain the large crack/lieback feature. Follow the crack to top out.
content.location: Start down low on the steepest part of the boulder. Just right of 'Flow Wolf'.

content.description: This ol' kitty has a long life and big stretches. Start the same as for 'Taco Cat' then veer right on crimps aiming for the arete hanging over a rock slab. Roughly 15 hand moves long and much harder if shorter. Last moves up the arete are spicy with the bad landing.
content.protection: 4 pads at least and spotter. Sloped rock slab for last half of problem.
content.location: Right most line on boulder. Start same as Taco Cat.

climbs.name: Mr. Owl Ate My Metal Worm
climbs.fa: Luke Kretschmar, Eric Hansen, Chris Hirsch, Dec 2019

content.description: Sit start the same as for Flow Wolf. Work up into underclings then head straight up to the angling crack. Traverse crack up and right to top out.
content.location: Center line of the gold face.

content.description:
Starts on small decent holds and moves up into the horizontal seam follow the seam right and up for a few moves before mantling over. This problem was put up on a tour from Brent Kertzman of the Breezy Point area in 2013. Will post photos once i find them. Not really worth doing but figured i would add it on here just for history. Name comes from Robbie and myself because of the rodent poo getting flung off the top when mantling. Since then it is clean and no poo exists.\

 Possible V1-2 variation: Start in a large dirty (for now) undercut in the bottom left of the face. Hike your feet up and slap for a couple slopers until you gain the gash. Work jugs, slopers, and crimps trending right to the peak of the boulder. I'm not entirely sure if this is the original or not, certainly the start doesn't match the original description, but it's loads of fun this way too.
content.protection: A pad for the hard moves, but several if you want to cover the entire landing (this traverses the length of the boulder).

content.description: Sit start in the middle of the golden face, make some interesting face moves up and right towards the jugs on the blunt corner. A final big move and its over.
content.location: Center of the East facing overhang. Top out at the peak of the boulder.

content.description: A trail side, eye-catching boulder. Hosts a few classic highball problems on solid rock.
